sources.author: The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences (PNAS)

cards.term: The mass of animals raised for slaughter on Earth now outweighs wildlife by a factor of what?
cards.text: The mass of animals raised for slaughter on Earth now outweighs wildlife by a factor of 15-to-1

cards.term: How many chickens are there for each person on the planet?
cards.text: For every person on the planet, there are approximately three chickens

cards.term: Meat and dairy account for what percent of global greenhouse gas emissions?
cards.text: Meat and dairy account for around 14.5% of global greenhouse gas emissions

sources.author: Science (American Association for the Advancement of Science)

cards.term: What is the greenhouse gas emissions per kilogram of beef from a beef herd?
cards.definition: ~60KgCO2e (CO2 emissions, or equivalent emissions from other GHGs such as methane)
cards.text: How do emissions from meat, dairy and other foods compare

cards.term: In 2017, 326 million Americans ate 80.67 pounds (36.67 kilos) of beef per person. How much carbon dioxide did this contribute to their carbon footprint?
cards.definition: Each kilo of beef is responsible for ~60 kilos of carbon dioxide emissions. Therefore the emissions, per person, in the United States was (36.67 * 60) = 2.2 tonnes. A sustainable per capita level of emissions is ~3 tonnes, and the current annual per capita emissions of U.S. citizens is ~17.5 tonnes.
cards.text: carbon dioxide emissions per head for beef in the united states

sources.author: University of California San Francisco Office of Sustainability (UCSF)

cards.term: Almond milk production produces around .2kg of CO2eq emissions per 300ml. Does this make it the most sustainable alternative to dairy milk?
cards.text: How sustainable is almond milk production?
cards.definition: Probably not. The production of almond milk requires large amounts of water. (In California, where 80% of the world’s almonds are produced, it has also been linked to unsustainable pesticide use.)

cards.term: Coffee is mostly grown in tropical regions. What is the main reason for its high carbon footprint?
cards.definition: Coffee production often involves using high amounts of nitrogen fertilisers.

sources.author: International Journal of Environmental Science and Technology

cards.term: Why does chocolate have such a high carbon footprint?
cards.definition: Chocolate’s climate impact is mostly caused by the land-use change required to produce cocoa.

cards.term: Emissions from food production depend on many factors. Outline 4 of these.
cards.definition: How much land, and of what type, has been converted, the type and amount of fertilisers used, animal welfare and upkeep, and feed types.

cards.term: How would you convert one tonne of carbon into one tonne of carbon dioxide?
cards.definition: Each molecule of CO2 has two oxygens, each with a mass of 16, and one carbon, with an atomic mass of 12. Its total mass is therefore 44 (16*2 + 12*1). Each molecule of carbon has one carbon, and an atomic mass 12. Therefore each C molecule is converted into 44/12 CO2 molecules. 1 tonne of carbon therefore equates to 3.67 tonnes of CO2.
cards.text: How to compare the mass of carbon and carbon dioxide.

title: What is the climate impact of eating meat and dairy?

ranked.text: List the top 5 foods with the highest GHG emissions, in any order.
